column3: Description
str

column2: Typhon's signature technique produces gale-force winds by propelling concentrated air through the nostrils─though mages recreate the gust externally
column3: for the sake of nasal integrity. In addition to buffeting foes backward
column4: it appears to have a detrimental effect on its target's mental state.

column2: Employed to great effect by Ultros
column3: this technique crushes adversaries beneath a phantom weight. Due to reticence in the scholastic community regarding certain forms of testing
column4: whether the weight applied feels like that of four full tonzes is a question that remains unanswered.

column3: easily mastered via defeat of a kraken
column4: fires a concentrated burst of water at one's opponent. As the liquid itself is conjured by manipulating aether to condense moisture in the air
column5: the technique remains effective regardless of whether or not its caster has access to a body of water.

column3: the Song of Torment carries in its melody a malicious enchantment. It ensnares the listener's spirit
column4: inducing phantom pain that soon becomes physical as the body struggles to process the mind's trauma.

column2: An industrial form of machina-based aetherial manipulation developed and adapted by the Allagan Empire. Through the compression of ambient lightning-aspected aether
column3: the caster (or casting machina) floods the vicinity with highly charged arcs of electricity.

column2: This spell manipulates wind- and earth-aspected aether to call forth the umbral
column3: imbuing exhaled air with miasma. Attempts to replicate the morbol's Bad Breath sans its inherent horrific stench have been unsuccessful
column4: thus it retains its title as the <Emphasis>foulest</Emphasis> of blue magicks.

column2: Replicating this technique requires magically altering one's own state of mind to mimic that of a zu. The flying strike that results surpasses normal physical limitations
column3: but requires dispensing with caution in favor of an all-consuming rage─the sensible mage will shield herself with aether first.

column2: The most quintessential of water-aspected blue magicks. A competent mage will not only use its bubbles to smother nearby enemies
column3: but also incorporate poisons
column4: sealing the fates of any survivors.

column2: Just like that all-too-well-known fixture in the arsenals of many earthy soulkin
column3: this technique creates a localized quake around the caster. According to legend
column4: the earth itself will appear to shatter under a true master of the spell.

column2: This technique pelts foes with seedlike aetherial orbs
column3: which then explode to release the soporific within. Scholars believe that similar defense mechanisms were originally developed by treants and other species vulnerable to vilekin in order to prevent their boring of holes and leeching of sap.
Bristle channels sheer animalistic rage into heightened spiritual and physical power. The blue mage will find that she can adapt this technique to increase her spells' potency.
though reportedly also found in Blaster's arsenal
column4: Mind Blast assaults nearby foes' perceptions
column5: tormenting them with the sensation of manifold cuts. Senses overwhelmed
column6: victims' bodies react as if perception were reality

column3: this spell saps a foe's aether
column4: a portion of which is then absorbed by the caster. In nature
column5: such habits first appeared in creatures such as bats and chigoes
column6: who naturalists theorize developed the ability to absorb nutrients via blood over the course of centuries.

column2: This spell creates an aetherial replica of the sort of bomb preferred by goblins. Of course
column3: goblin bombs acquire their combustive force through the use of magically enhanced gunpowder
column4: so mimicking this effect with aether alone requires no small amount of effort
column5: but the results are...explosive.

column2: Highly famed─and feared─due to its frequent use by cactuars
column3: 1000 Needles showers one's surroundings with a hail of slim projectiles. Despite their magical nature
column4: the velocity at which the blue mage's pseudo-spines are propelled ensures that they are quite as painful as the real thing.

column2: This technique mimics the Drill Cannons of machina by winding aetherial currents until they resemble rapidly spinning projectiles. Like the physical drills upon which they are patterned
column3: these projectiles excel at penetrating stone.
this technique requires using the position of one's own eyes to anchor arcane geometries in which to concentrate aether. The user then expels the aether
column4: propelled by ill will
column5: in the direction of his gaze─though this tends to earn him a fair bit of ire in return.

column3: tonberries' predilection for sharpened knives is well known. By manipulating aether to harness feelings of resentment
column4: one hones a keener blade for driving into the heart of the enemy. Naturally
column5: being beset by this attack while unable to move is a uniquely harrowing experience.

column2: To utilize this simple teleportation spell
column3: casters must create an aetherial current upon which to travel between their location and the desired position. Though this is only effective over short distances
column4: it is nevertheless an invaluable tool in the event that one needs to beat a hasty retreat.

column3: the jet of flame produced by this technique manifests from a burst of fire-aspected aether. Certain weapons produce similar effects; however
column4: this is not through aetherial manipulation
column5: but rather the copious use of highly flammable liquid.

column2: Originally developed as a means of defense from flesh-eating beasts
column3: this favorite of the Qiqirn tribes produces a shockwave as its user strikes together palms filled with concentrated aether
column4: leaving foes witless.

column2: Perhaps best known as the unsettling hallmark of the cyclops
column3: Glower involves funneling aether through the eyes as if they were arcane circles─much like its sister spell
column4: The Look. Its highly concentrated aether strikes foes like a levinbolt
column5: leaving their skin singed and muscles seizing.

column2: A magical imitation of warmachina technology
column3: this technique allows the user to fire a barrage of aetherial missiles. When efficacious─which
column4: bear in mind
column5: is not guaranteed─it sends a shock through the foe that appears to resonate more the greater their vitality.

column2: White Wind imbues a localized current of air with purified aether
column3: distributing its curative effects throughout the vicinity. Though powerful for such a simple spell
column4: the purification of sufficient aether requires significant magical exertion on the part of the caster
column5: and thus should be used sparingly.

column3: this technique converts all of the user's life force to an aetherial poison that is then injected into a single adversary. Suffice it to say that
column4: as with the physical sting of the wespe
column5: it should not be relied upon in but the most dire of circumstances.

column2: Credited as the source of the “bomb” voidsent family's name
column3: Self-destruct
column4: when used by blue mages
column5: converts the entirety of its caster's energy into fire-aspected aether to cause an explosion. The application of oil has been observed to make it more effective─though likely also more painful.

column2: At times used by self-sacrificing spirits of the dead roaming the New World
column3: this technique consumes the entirety of one's being to fully restore both the body and mind of another. Though the sacrifice required is great
column4: the use of this spell is a deed not soon forgotten.

column2: This technique covers the blue mage's body in oil
column3: much like a gigantoad's slime would its own
column4: allowing the caster to slip and slide away from foes' attacks. Though most consider it uncouth at best
column5: make no mistake─its devotees are few

column2: A primitive type of curse cast by giants in the New World
column3: this spell sunders opponents' defenses by breaking their spirits. Pairing it with strong offensive magic allows the blue mage to weaken and strike down foe after foe without cease.
Sticky Tongue is employed by gigantoads
column4: who extend said lengthy and unusually adhesive appendages to capture distant prey. The blue magic rendition utilizes a far more sanitary aetherial “tongue
column5: ” but the principle is the same.

column2: Karlabos performs Tail Screw by collecting turbulent aether in the tip of its tail
column3: then unleashing it at once as a violent whorl that rips foes' lives from their bodies. This is notoriously difficult to imitate
column4: due to the challenges inherent in attempting to control such a volatile aetherial vortex.

column3: commonly used by ahrimans and similar voidsent
column4: takes advantage of the hubris that living creatures tend to fall prey to upon reaching certain malmstones in development
column5: targeting mental weaknesses to give foes a paralyzing reminder of their own fallibility.

column2: This technique imitates a peculiar flute wrested from the grasp of a vanquished voidsent. Said creature was initially welcomed as a god by those New World peoples who worship the moon
column3: but it soon became clear to them that the flute was the true source of its power and cruel authority.

column2: Oft cast by voidsent in the New World
column3: this mortal curse merely hints that one's time may be nigh. For particularly suggestible opponents
column4: however
column5: this is enough─the looming specter of death will send them leaping to their graves.

column2: Protected by only a dainty layer of scales
column3: some Indigo Deep-dwellers' survival has come to depend on aetherial manipulation─this technique included. By reducing the amount of aether used for offense
column4: more becomes available for the creation of a strong─if flashy─barrier.

column2: Favored by certain types of voidsent
column3: this spell─technically a curse
column4: cast upon oneself─converts the malice of attackers into aetherial spikes of ice
column5: impaling them each time they strike. The more furious their flurries
column6: the more pain they cause themselves─poetic justice

column2: Scholars theorize that this particular spell was born of the variety of aetherial manipulation often performed by northern rams to survive the harsh climes of high elevations─but when ram became chimerical head
column3: it began to favor offense over defense.

column2: The blue mage's ability to precisely direct volatile levin to form the smooth ring produced by this spell is owed to the chimera from which the technique was learned─and whose control of lightning aether was
column3: in turn
column4: owed to its draconic head.

column2: A variant on a salamander specialty
column3: Peculiar Light disperses radiance naturally emitted during spellcasting into a half-globe
column4: clouding victims' vision. Thus unbeknownst to them
column5: malignant aether lurking within the rapidly reflecting beams renders them more susceptible to further aetherial assaults.

column2: Ink Jet can be considered a more advanced form of Water Cannon─fitting
column3: as both come courtesy of the kraken. The spell infuses aetherially concentrated water with whatever impure substances are most readily available to create and expel a synthetic “ink
column4: ” blinding opponents.

column3: in the wild
column4: violently regurgitates its latest pescatarian meal at predators as a defense mechanism. In blue magic trials

column4: though its defensive properties are superlative
column5: its weight makes it impossible for the caster to move while under its aegis.

column3: this spell imbues a long-headed spear called an “angon”─or rather
column4: an aetherial replica of the same─with fire-aspected aether and propels it across the field at enemy combatants.

column3: as swift and brutal as most of Garuda's skills
column4: puts the force of a gale behind a storm of sharp plumes
column5: afflicting foes with innumerable cuts and lashes that cause lingering agony.

column2: Necessitating the skill to manipulate currents beneath the earth as Ifrit does

column4: creating an effect similar to that of a volcano.

column2: In a devastating recreation of one of Titan's most fearsome techniques
column3: Mountain Buster strikes opponents with an upheaval of earth-aspected aether
column4: as if the land itself were ripping free of its confines to pulverize its defilers─or any unfortunate bystanders
column5: as it were.

column3: never so imposing as when cast by Ramuh
column4: calls down a bolt from the heavens. Though measurements are difficult to come by
column5: its power is thought to far exceed that of levinbolts found in nature─indeed
column6: it more closely resembles a warhammer crashing to the earth.

column3: beloved of Shiva
column4: the blue mage calls forth a bow of aether from which she fires a hail of razor-sharp icicles. Those who knew the lady Ysayle believe that Glass Dance may have taken form from her memories of observing hunters in Tailfeather.

column3: inspired by Leviathan
column4: creates an aqueous film of water collected from the atmosphere. Though a veil in the sense of offering protection from outside forces
column5: it also functions as a mirror
column6: reflecting foes' aether back upon them.

column2: So fierce as to match the gales that pierce Abalathia's Spine
column3: the gusting wind produced by this spell is commonly put to use by wild griffins in driving trespassers from their jealously guarded territory.

column2: This technique originates with the living liquid
column3: which coalesces about a hydrate core that allows it to dispense its own fluid in a violent flood. The magically reproduced version
column4: correctly applied

column2: Owing to the unique refrigerant in its saliva

column3: in nature
column4: employed by the voracious sea serpent

column3: it is first necessary to replicate the panzer doll's fearsome spear
column4: which is then swung in an arc to cut foes down quicker than they can blink.

column4: the universe
column5: and everything─an experience to which the mind reacts by shutting down entirely

column4: however
column5: be harnessed by the mage to disrupt certain harmonious aetherial frequencies and nullify their beneficial effects.

column3: this technique

column3: this spell twists its way into a victim's mind
column4: causing such acute distress that the body's organs are forced to shut down.

column3: fooling foes into feeling as if they have met the singularly unpleasant fate of being fired upon by Garlean magitek and causing their bodies to react accordingly.

column4: the savvy mage can render a foe entirely immobile.

The Whalaqee are generally willing to pass on this close-quarter technique
column3: which allows the mage to harness his own feelings of desperation at being driven closer to death and launch a last-ditch offensive. The name of the creature who originally possessed it

A versatile technique utilized and perfected by Genbu

column4: with even low-flying cloudkin falling victim to its inexorable pull.

column4: the Blue Mages' Guild opted to limit the flame's intensity to a gentle sear.

column2: Part of the nixie's watery repertoire
column3: this technique sends a swirling deluge crashing over enemies─rather too rough for its original purpose of delighting children
column4: but it makes a fine addition to the blue mage's arsenal.

column2: While magic is ordinarily woven with words and symbols
column3: this spell employed by the dread creation Therion harnesses the power of emotion to beget destruction. It is said that
column4: if one can cling to the desire for oblivion
column5: it is possible to sustain the ruinous effect indefinitely.

column2: The faerie king Titania's signature move
column3: this spell embodies the disdain
column4: pity
column5: and delight that men's fleeting lives inspire in the fae folk. By weaving layers upon layers of runes to create a deadly maelstrom of magic
column6: you too can remind others of their mortality...until you inevitably meet your own demise.
